metadata.bible_text: The Parable of the Tenants (Matthew 21:33-46 / Mark 12:1-12 / Luke 20:9-19)
metadata.sermon_start_end: I do not relish preaching which is joined too closely to current events, since it can become merely the preacher's comment on the passing scene. [...] Christians tell the world, 'They won't be able to kill us off.'
metadata.liturgical_context: Sunday following the funeral of Mrs. Alberta King (July 1974)
metadata.historical_context: Delivered shortly after the assassination of Alberta Williams King (mother of MLK Jr.) at Ebenezer Baptist Church, Atlanta.
metadata.notes: A seminal example of African American homiletics responding to trauma through the lens of theodicy and social critique.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: Proctor utilizes vivid, sensory imagery to bridge the gap between the sanctuary and the street. He masterfully contrasts the 'Lord’s Prayer' with the 'staccato thunder of the gun,' creating a visceral auditory dissonance. The imagery of the 'black-and-white organ keyboard' stained with 'innocent blood' serves as a powerful synecdoche for the desecration of the holy. His use of the 'runway' metaphor to transition from earthly reality to 'everlasting hills' provides a spatial dimension to the sermon's movement. The imagery is not merely decorative; it functions as a 'cinematic' witness to the tragedy, fulfilling Paul Scott Wilson’s 'show, don't tell' mandate by placing the listener in the limousine and the choir loft.
quotes: The news raced through the nation, as if on the angry wings of tragedy.
It was a blazing, hot day in Atlanta, and the two ladies sat on the rear seat of the limousine.
They had seen innocent blood on the black-and-white organ keyboard.
strengths: Strong sensory contrast between the music of the liturgy and the violence of the shooting.
Effective use of spatial metaphors (runway, hills, stars) to guide the listener's perspective.
Vivid characterization of the 'poisoned atmosphere' using chemical and meteorological metaphors.
improvement_points: The metaphor of 'mechanical and scientific achievements' as 'intoxication' is slightly clichéd in 20th-century rhetoric.
Some descriptions of 'merchants of fiery speech' could be more concrete to avoid becoming abstract tropes.
The 'runway' metaphor, while effective, is briefly dropped and could have been sustained through the transition.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly 'showing' in the narrative sections (the drive, the funeral); shifts to 'telling' during the social critique of gun laws.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is precise and avoids the 'Canaanite' jargon often found in traditionalist preaching. Proctor uses 'stewardship of language' (McEntyre) by naming specific sins: greed, profit, and 'conspicuous display of prosperity.' He is careful to distinguish between 'sentiment' and 'emotion,' particularly in his description of the 'laugh of self-contempt' versus the 'tender laugh of love.' However, there is a slight tendency toward rhetorical lists ('Greed! Profit! Selfishness!') which, while effective for oral delivery, borders on generalization. His naming of God through various biblical titles provides a rich, nuanced theological vocabulary that avoids simplistic definitions.
quotes: We have paraded conspicuous display of prosperity before people trapped in the prison house of poverty.
We have not laughed the tender laugh of love at our one institution, but the laugh of self-contempt.
The lame excuse is given that 'when guns are outlawed, only outlaws will have guns.'
strengths: Clear, unpretentious language that addresses complex social issues directly.
Honest self-critique of the clergy, avoiding moral superiority.
Precise naming of the 'poisoned atmosphere' components (drugs, anger, bitter talk).
improvement_points: The transition to the 'kingdom of evil' uses somewhat broad, sweeping terms ('Western world', 'European person').
The list of God's names (El Shaddai, Daysman) is evocative but could be more integrated into the specific 'Why' of the sermon.
Occasional use of 'everybody knows' weakens the precision of the argument.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Religious jargon is minimal; biblical names for God are used rhetorically to evoke majesty rather than to obscure meaning.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon exhibits the rhythmic excellence characteristic of the African American preaching tradition. Proctor uses parallelism and repetition ('A president... A senator... The nation's moral leader...') to build rhetorical momentum. The cadence of the 'Lord’s Prayer' interspersed with the narrative of the shooting creates a haunting staccato rhythm. The conclusion, with its rhythmic repetition of the hymns and the refrain 'They won't be able to kill us off,' functions like a musical coda that resolves the tension. The sentence structure varies effectively between short, punchy questions and long, flowing narrative descriptions, ensuring an oral 'flow' that prevents the text from feeling like 'paper language.'
quotes: Why murder in church? Why murder in a black church! Why murder in a black church committed by a black man?
Midst the music of that prayer, bullets ring out through the sanctuary, the house of God.
They won't be able to kill us off.
strengths: Excellent use of anaphora (repetition at the start of sentences) to build intensity.
Natural oral cadence that facilitates 'hearing' the text.
Effective integration of hymnody as a rhythmic and emotional anchor.
improvement_points: The middle section on social critique loses some of the poetic rhythm found in the opening and closing.
Some sentences in the 'vineyard' section are slightly repetitive in a way that slows the pace unnecessarily.
The transition 'Let me take off toward the hills and stars' feels a bit abrupt in its rhythmic shift.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Decidedly oral language; the text is clearly designed for performance and communal hearing.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The sermon demonstrates a high level of micro-aesthetic quality. Proctor’s language is sensory and rhythmic, successfully 'reframing' a traumatic event through vivid imagery and the cadence of the Black Church tradition. He avoids the pitfall of abstract theological jargon, opting instead for a 'stewardship of language' that is both precise and evocative. The contrast between the sacred space of the organ and the violence of the gun is handled with poetic sensitivity, ensuring the 'how' of the message reinforces the 'what' of the gospel’s resilience.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Homiletical Plot' (Lowry). It begins with an 'upsetting of the equilibrium'—the shock of the murder—and moves through a series of 'Why' questions that deepen the conflict. Proctor does not offer easy answers; he moves from social/political causes to the 'poisoned atmosphere' and finally to the 'metaphysical' reality of evil. The turning point occurs with the Parable of the Tenants, shifting from the 'Why' of human tragedy to the 'What' of God’s persistence. The conclusion provides a 'resolution' that does not erase the pain but sustains the tension through the hope of the 'others' God will raise up. It is a dynamic journey from the limousine to the 'everlasting hills.'
quotes: What meaning do you make of the murder of Mrs. King?
Let us move along here as on a runway before we take off toward the everlasting hills.
He will not give up. He has a plan.
strengths: Strong narrative opening that grounds the sermon in a specific, shared trauma.
Logical and emotional progression from the immediate event to systemic issues to cosmic evil.
The use of the 'runway' metaphor provides a clear structural signal to the audience.
improvement_points: The transition from the social critique of gun laws to the 'poisoned atmosphere' could be more fluid.
The 'vineyard' parable is slightly long and risks losing the immediate tension of the Alberta King story.
The 'Why murder at all?' section feels a bit like a detour before returning to the specific 'Why' of the church.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from 'trouble' to 'grace' (Wilson), structured as an unfolding mystery.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest aesthetic strength. Proctor achieves a profound 'reframing' (Cilliers) by mapping the murder of Alberta King onto the Parable of the Tenants. The 'servants' of the parable are identified with the 'prophets' of the civil rights movement, and the 'son' with the ultimate sacrifice. The integration is organic; the biblical text provides the 'frame' through which the contemporary tragedy is interpreted. He respects the 'strangeness' of the text while making it urgently relevant. The synthesis of the 'black-and-white organ keyboard' and the 'vineyard' creates a new space where the congregation can process their grief without losing their faith.
quotes: Somebody said his name was Elijah or Jeremiah... Somebody said he was named Hosea or Isaiah.
In a crowded church, they had seen innocent blood on the black-and-white organ keyboard.
They killed Martin, A. D. is dead, and now they've killed Bunch... They won't be able to kill us off.
strengths: Masterful 'reframing' of the King family's suffering within the biblical narrative of the vineyard.
Surprising yet natural connection between the 'keepers' of the vineyard and the 'merchants of hate.'
The application flows directly from the narrative logic of the parable.
improvement_points: The identification of the servants (Elijah, Hosea) is a bit speculative and could be more grounded in the text's own logic.
The 'mechanical and scientific achievements' section feels less integrated into the 'vineyard' metaphor than other parts.
A deeper exploration of the 'tenants' in the contemporary context could have sharpened the social critique.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes; reality is reframed from a scene of hopeless slaughter to a scene of divine persistence.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: The sermon is an 'open work of art' (Stark) in that it does not resolve the 'Why' with a simple, dogmatic answer. Proctor admits the 'mind has not been able to get that far.' By ending with the quote from Daddy King ('They won't be able to kill us off'), he leaves the future open to the congregation’s own participation in God’s plan. However, the section on gun control and social critique is more 'closed' and prescriptive, which is appropriate for the prophetic tradition but slightly reduces the 'polyvalence' of the aesthetic experience. The tension between the 'already' of the murder and the 'not yet' of God’s victory is sustained until the end.
quotes: What will he do? ... He will not give up. He has a plan.
They won't be able to kill us off.
strengths: Honors the 'ambivalence of existence' by acknowledging the shock and the 'poisoned atmosphere.'
The ending is an invitation to resilience rather than a moralistic checklist.
Leaves room for the mystery of evil ('mightier than we think').
improvement_points: The social critique section ('Have you? Have I?') is somewhat coercive in its rhetorical questioning.
The 'plan' of God is presented with a certainty that might slightly close the space for those still in deep lament.
The conclusion could have invited more specific 'appropriation' by the hearer.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Primarily open; it invites the hearer into a narrative of resilience rather than imposing a closed system of truths.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic quality is excellent. Proctor constructs a narrative arc that moves from the 'trouble' of a specific murder to the 'grace' of God’s cosmic persistence. The integration of the King family’s tragedy with the Parable of the Tenants is a masterclass in 'reframing,' allowing the biblical text to speak into the contemporary trauma without flattening its complexity. While some sections are rhetorically 'closed' for prophetic emphasis, the overall structure remains an 'open work' that invites the congregation into a shared identity of resilience.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: Proctor successfully avoids religious kitsch by refusing to offer 'cheap comfort.' He does not skip over the 'stench' of the tragedy or the 'poison' of the community. The sermon is not a 'happy ending' story; it is a story of survival amidst ongoing slaughter. He distinguishes between 'sentiment' (the crude jokes about the church) and 'authentic emotion' (the grief of Daddy King). The 'Space for Grace' is opened precisely because the 'Space for Lament' is taken seriously. There is no 'pre-chewed' emotion here; the shock is real, and the hope is hard-won.
examples_of_kitsch: The potential for kitsch in the 'Lord's Prayer' sequence is avoided by the sudden interruption of 'bullets ring out.'
The 'Rev. Leroy skits' are cited as examples of the 'kitsch' (vulgar caricature) that the preacher rejects.
authentic_moments: The raw dialogue with Daddy King: 'They killed Martin, A. D. is dead, and now they've killed Bunch.'
The admission of the preacher's own failure and the church's 'conspicuous display of prosperity.'
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain the focus on the 'ugly, determined thing' that is evil to ensure the grace remains 'costly' rather than 'cheap.'

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Space is opened for grace by acknowledging the 'uttermost of Godness' required to match the power of evil. Proctor does not 'seal' the sermon with moralism; instead, he points to the 'unavailable' action of God who 'will raise up that Son.' The tension between the 'barren land' and the 'mighty hand' is sustained through the use of hymns. By centering the sermon on the 'God who will not be defeated' rather than 'human effort that must not fail,' he creates a genuine 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers).
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes; the tension between the 'staccato thunder of the gun' and the 'hope for years to come' remains palpable.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: Yes; the 'kingdom of evil' is treated as a formidable mystery that humans cannot manage alone.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails, though it is preceded by a sharp prophetic call to social responsibility.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Continue to emphasize the 'Godness' of God as the only adequate response to the 'ugliness' of evil.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically powerful response to a moment of profound communal trauma. Samuel DeWitt Proctor demonstrates a sophisticated grasp of homiletic aesthetics, moving beyond 'Die Aufgabe der Predigt' to a 'performance' of the gospel that is both timely and timeless. The sermon’s strength lies in its 'reframing' of the Alberta King murder through the Parable of the Tenants, creating a narrative arc that leads the hearer from shock to resilient hope. The language is rhythmic and sensory, avoiding the 'kitsch' of easy comfort in favor of the 'sober beauty' of a faith that survives violence. While the social critique sections are rhetorically more 'closed,' they serve the 'dramaturgy' of the sermon by grounding the cosmic struggle in the 'squalor and misery' of the 1970s urban context. Proctor acts as a 'witness' (Long), showing the congregation the 'blazing flash' of the gun and the 'solid rock' of the faith simultaneously.
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'reframing' of contemporary tragedy through the Parable of the Tenants.
Vivid, sensory imagery that creates a 'cinematic' witness to the event.
Authentic emotional depth that avoids religious kitsch and cheap comfort.
improvement_points_top_3: Fluidity in transitions between social critique and narrative sections.
Greater precision in the 'Western world' critique to avoid sweeping generalizations.
Sustaining the 'runway' metaphor more consistently through the middle of the sermon.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits the 'Reframing' of Johan Cilliers and the 'Imagery' focus of Paul Scott Wilson.
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to those experiencing communal grief, seeking a synthesis between social justice and traditional faith.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Explore more 'polyvalent' endings that leave the 'Why' even more open to the mystery of God.
Use more 'legato' rhythms in the social critique sections to match the poetic quality of the narrative.
Experiment with 'showing' the systemic greed through a specific story rather than 'telling' it through a list.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: Through the lens of homiletic aesthetics, this sermon is a 'strong' (7.9) example of how form and content can be inseparably linked to process trauma. It successfully opens 'Space for Grace' in a context where evil seems to have the final word. It is a model of 'stewardship of language' and 'dramaturgical movement,' transforming a site of murder into a site of theological perception.
